item.title: The CJEU's decision on the importance of parenthood in EU law slips away from us.
item.description:
Steve Peers Most EU laws and court decisions on sex discrimination focus on improving women’s job opportunities and ensuring equal treatment in the workplace. A recent ruling by the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) in the Maistrellis case tackles these issues from a different perspective: a father’s access to parental leave when the mother isn’t employed or looking for work. This judgment brings up important questions about how EU employment and discrimination laws affect family life...

item.title: Contemplating EU Gender Equality Law on Surrogate Mothers' Day in Court
item.description:
Steve Peers The desire to have children has always been deeply understood, especially for women facing medical obstacles to childbirth. Adoption was the traditional solution, but recent decades have introduced alternatives like IVF and surrogacy. While the EU doesn’t directly regulate these practices, it does address maternity leave through the Pregnant Workers’ Directive. The Directive on Sex Discrimination in Employment further tackles the employment aspects of pregnancy. This directive prohibits discrimination against women undergoing IVF treatment even before pregnancy, as established by the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) in the Mayr case...

item.title: The rights of pregnant workers and the free movement rights of EU citizens
item.description:
Steve Peers Jessy Saint Prix, a young woman from France, relocated to Britain in 2006 to pursue a teaching career. Her experience led her to learn much more about EU law and the English legal system than she expected. After working in the UK as a teaching assistant for a year, she began a teacher training program (PGCE). During the program, she became pregnant and decided to pause her studies to register with a teaching agency...

item.description:

The case was brought by a French woman, represented by British lawyers, who argued that the law violated several articles of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), including the right to freedom of religion, expression, and association, as well as protection from discrimination...

item.title: Is the EU truly dedicated to addressing violence against women, or is it just empty words?
item.description:
Catherine Briddick, Martin James Departmental Lecturer in Gender and Forced Migration at the Refugee Studies Centre of the University of Oxford - @CateBriddick Background The European Union (EU) has a core legal commitment to fight discrimination, including sex-based discrimination, and to promote gender equality. However, it has faced ongoing and valid criticism for not upholding these commitments, especially regarding its treatment of female migrants and refugees. Therefore, the Commission’s 2016 announcement that the EU would sign and ratify the Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence Against Women (the Istanbul Convention) was welcomed by activists and academics...

item.title: Is it against EU law to tolerate discrimination against women who are breastfeeding?
item.description:
Steve Peers Nigel Farage, leader of the UK Independence Party, recently expressed that while he personally had no issue with public breastfeeding, businesses should set their own rules. He suggested businesses could ask breastfeeding women to move to a less conspicuous area, implying a discreet approach would be preferable. His statement was prompted by incidents where a restaurant asked a woman to cover her baby while breastfeeding and another establishment suggested using the disabled restroom for this purpose...

item.title: EU Referendum Briefing 6: The Impact on EU Employment and Equality Law Post-Brexit
item.description:
Professor Steve Peers suggests that while some claim there would be a “bonfire of rights” if the UK left the EU, particularly in employment and equality, others argue that the EU has no bearing on these laws in the UK. This post will demonstrate that EU law has significantly improved employment and equality rights in the UK, especially for women in the workplace. A study of all UK cases reaching the EU court concerning these issues reveals that 60% of cases involving equal treatment for women resulted in findings that UK law was inadequate, leading to improved workplace protections for women...
